bioghist.p: In 1982, the Center for the History of Chemistry (CHOC) was launched as a pilot project of the University of Pennsylvania and the American Chemical Society (ACS). In 1987 CHOC was incorporated as a not-for-profit organization, now named the National Foundation for the History of Chemistry, by joint action of the ACS and AIChE, the Center's third sponsor. In 1992 the Chemical Heritage Foundation (CHF) assumed its present name to better reflect the interdisciplinary nature of the sciences and industries it serves and the widening public scope of its activities. CHF publishes a variety of books and other materials for readers interested in the history of the chemical and molecular sciences and industries.

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of records relating to the publications of the Chemical Heritage Foundation. The materials fall into three broad categories: records of the Chemical Heritage newsmagazine, administrative files from the publications department, and records of the American Chemical Society/Chemical Heritage Foundation book series from the files of series editor of Jeffrey L. Sturchio. Chemical Heritage records include: notes on layout and design; drafts of articles, reviews, and announcements; correspondence with authors; letters to the editor; requests for review copies of books; background reference articles; research on images for articles; and planning documents for future issues of the magazine. Publications department files include: monthly reports and inventories; guides to archives and corporate histories; publication information on CHF brochures, catalogues, and books; requests for back issues of magazines and brochures; slide requests; research material for possible use in future publications; and general office administrative files. ACS/CHF book series records include: Advisory and Editorial Board meeting minutes; series marketing materials; correspondence regarding publication and marketing; rejected proposals, and accepted proposals including drafts and correspondence; and an annotated proof copy of an ACS-CHF book on Nobel Laureates.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
